body: I want to add that @Ktar5 had found there's a sharp framerate difference between LWJGL2 and LWJGL3 on their machine when running [my game/demo CaveCops](https://github.com/tommyettinger/CaveCopshttps://github.com/tommyettinger/CaveCops), with no code changes other than adding a desktop/LWJGL2 module (core is unchanged). Even on integrated graphics, CaveCops can get over 200 FPS, so the LWJGL3 code running at 54 FPS on a high-end gaming machine is concerning to me. I think @Ktar5 can test with vsync enabled on a machine with a 144Hz monitor; if that goes from 144 FPS on LWJGL2 to 54FPS on LWJGL3, that sounds like a significant bug.
In response to @tommyettinger I have tested before on my 144hz monitor and got fps ranging from 80-130 so it seems like a very interesting bug that could be going on

There is a possibility that the root cause could be the same as #4274 but I believe that my issue is a more focused and accurate description of a single bug, whereas the aforementioned issue seems to talk about fullscreen vsync issues, multi-window issues, and fps issues, whereas I am experiencing single-window fps issues (seemingly) regardless of vsync enabling or disabling and only in windowed mode.
It seems now that this bug only happens when I activate my second monitor and move the window onto that second, external monitor.

Can confirm that this is not a problem with LibGDX but with LWJGL3, I'll continue to post updates here as I learn more.

Here's a gif of a strictly LWJGL3 game running poorly with vsync enabled. https://i.imgur.com/J7hJq8n.gifv

Just wanted to add that I am experiencing the same issue when upgrading from 1.9.9 -> 1.9.11-SNAPSHOT. I was unable to upgrade to 1.9.10 due to Tiled Map bug with animated tiles. I'll debug a big more and see if I can pinpoint any more helpful debugging information. For now I have reverted back to 1.9.9

SOLUTION BELOW

Problem: vsync isn't meant to be used on windowed applications, so when a windowed application has vsync enabled it causes errors. As well, vsync + multiple monitors running at different resolutions and/or refresh rates causes even more strange issues. In order to fix this you should be disabling vsync whenever the game is in windowed mode, and limiting the FPS by using the Sync class outlined here: http://forum.lwjgl.org/index.php?topic=6582.0

Note: you need to make sure to disable vsync every time the game goes into windowed and enable the sync class delay, and then re-enable vsync and (I don't think it makes a difference, but:) disable sync class when in fullscreen.

Feel free to ping me if you need assistance.

@Ktar5 thanks for the update, i'lll give it a try!
Also, is that an appropriate long term fix? I'm wondering if this issue should still stay open. :)
Yes it is the appropriate long term fix @kennycason however it _should_ at some point be implemented into libgdx or lwjgl so that the user doesn't even have to know about solving this issue
@Ktar5 interestingly this did not seem to resolve the issue for me. I'll give it a more diligent try/test over the weekend.

issue.title: LWJGL 3 backend V-Sync problem on desktop
issue.body:
All my monitors work on 60 hz:

### Issue details
- If I use **LWJGL 3.0, 3.1**, coded V-Sync ON (and forced V-Sync on Radeon Drivers), I get **30 FPS** (windowed mode).
- If I use **LWJGL 3.0, 3.1**, coded V-Sync ON (and DISABLED V-Sync on Radeon Drivers), I get **60 FPS** (windowed mode).
- If I use **LWJGL 2.x**, coded V-Sync ON (and forced V-Sync on Radeon Drivers), I get **60 FPS** (windowed mode) as expected on my monitor Hz.
- If I use **LWJGL 2.x**, coded V-Sync ON (and DISABLED V-Sync on Radeon Drivers), I get **60 FPS** (windowed mode)

### Expected results
I should always get 60 FPS as my monitor expect, instead of 30.

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
libGDX 1.9.4, 1.9.5, 1.9.6, 1.9.7-SNAPSHOT

#### Please select the affected platforms
- [ ] Android

- [x] Windows

- [ ] MacOS

Windows 10 + AMD + Forced v-sync on drivers = **30 FPS problem appear**.
Windows 10 + NVIDIA + Forced v-sync on drivers = 60 FPS.
Ubuntu 17.10 + NVIDIA+ Forced v-sync on drivers = 60 FPS.

My general PC specs: Windows 10 pro 64 bits. AMD FX-8350 8cores@4Ghz, motherboard Gigabyte GA-970A-DS3P, 16Gb ram, AMD Radeon R9 280x, SSD 840 EVO 500Gb.

_NOTE_: Using latest drivers on all PC up today.

issue.title: Switching to fullscreen causes CPU to spike
issue.body:
#### Issue details
I am making an LibGdx build using the Lwjgl3 backend 'gdx-backend-lwjgl3'.
I am using Kotlin.

When I run the desktop application (after enabling vsync) in windowed mode, the CPU is about 1-2%.
When I switch it to fullscreen with an Alt+Enter toggle I created, the task manager says that
the java process is taking up to 50%. I have a multi-monitor desktop, so I can look at both.
Also, when in fullscreen, the FPS seems unlimited, as the logger show it going above 4,000
despite the fact that my Lwjgl3ApplicationConfiguration has vsync set to true.

If I force it to use vsync after it goes to fullscreen (Using Gdx.graphics.setVsync(true) ), the logger says that the fps is at 60, but the CPU utilization does not go down.

When the is windowed, but stretched to fill most of the screen, the cpu utilization is still low.
This only happens when it goes to fullscreen  or starts in fullscreen.

#### Reproduction steps/code
1) Clone build  here: https://github.com/Anti-Alias/pokemaker-core

2) Run application in cmd or git bash using:
gradlew desktop:run
or
./gradlew desktop:run

3) Open task manager on a Windows machine and note the cpu usage.

3) Press Alt+Enter and notice change in task manager's cpu usage for that java process.
You will need at least two monitors to test this.


#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
LibGdx version:     1.9.7
gdx backend:        gdx-backend-lwjgl3 : 1.9.7

#### Please select the affected platforms
Windows 10

issue.title: Set vsync setting again after enabling fullscreen mode.
issue.body: On Windows, the vsync setting is ignored if fullscreen mode is enabled. Setting the vsync mode again fixes this, see #5826.
